captions.text:
When travelling in London Town
it's easy to raise a frown

so please do try not to forget
these simple rules of etiquette

Platforms are really quite long
so it just seems rather wrong

to stand together in one place
(with someone's backpack in your face).

By moving down a little more
you'll be much quicker through the door.

Now the pushy-type that jumps aboard
right ahead of the travelling hoard

refuses to let others out
(even though they scream and shout)

is someone who deserves up out pity for not
knowing how to travel in this city

And whilst it's tempting to obstruct the doors
you should know what this can cause

it doesn't just delay the train,
but can mean damage, hurt and pain.

Now we don't mean to chide
but try to move along inside

so fellow travellers won't have to face
an invasion of their personal space.

And when feeling sick or suffering pain,
it's tempting to try to stop the train.

but reaching out for the alarm
can actually cause a lot more harm.

It takes us longer to get to you
and stops the trains from going through.

So that's the simple explanation
why you should wait until the station.

We love those papers you get for free
but, we're sure that you'll agree,

that love very quickly turns to hate
if they block the doors and make us late.

So, and this is just to let you know,
take them with you when you go.

Could all travellers take heed,
and offer seats to those in need.

We know that may seem rather bold
but please don't wait until you're told.

Now all this isn't meant to preach,
just to remind, inform and teach.

Because, and we don't mean to flatter.
To us, all your journeys matter.

comments.text: I loved every single one of these posters while traveling through London!﻿
comments.author: The Animatorr

comments.text:
@Geoff Marshall - on some lines, the trains are older and therefore more 
primitive. When the alarm is pulled, the brake is activated immediately. If 
the train is in a tunnel, the driver then must walk through the 
possibly-crowded train to reach the alarm to reset it before being able to 
continue. On newer trains this is not a problem since the drivers are able 
to override the brake application after talking to the passenger - but it's 
a much less clear message for adverts to explain the differences between 
stock to people than it is just to say to always wait for the station ;).

EDIT: Actually, I might be wrong about this - my memory might be playing 
tricks on me. Hmm.﻿
comments.author: Muzer0

comments.text:
So when someone had a heart attack on my train (and I gave them first aid), 
we pulled the alarm immediately between stations and the driver was able to 
speak to Line Control who alerted the next station so that when we pulled 
in there were people already there waiting to help.

If we'd have waited UNTIL we 'd got to that station, THEN pulled the alarm 
it would have taken them time to then reach us.  So how is this better? I 
can't see a reason for not pulling the alarm in-between stations when 
someone's health is at stake. Serious question, would love a reply. 
 thanks.﻿

comments.text:
Please remember, don't forget, NEVER leave the bathroom wet, nor leave the 
soap still in the water (that's a thing you never ought'er); and as you've 
been so often told, NEVER let the hot run cold; nor leave the towels upon 
the floor, nor keep the bath an hour or more when other folks are wanting 
one - just don't forget IT ISN'T DONE; and if you really do the thing, 
there's not the SLIGHTEST need to sing.
